title: How Does Prepaid Compare to Traditional Cell Service?
description: Prepaid cell phone plans are gaining popularity as people look for easy ways to save money on core household expenses. However, potential customers are hesitant to switch for various reasons. The post How Does Prepaid Compare to Traditional Cell Service? appeared first on Well Kept Wallet.
author: Josh Patoka
excerpt: Prepaid phone plans often provide similar coverage and all the talk, text, and data you need at more affordable prices. Here's how.
text: Prepaid cell phone plans are gaining popularity as people look for easy ways to save money on core household expenses. However, potential customers are hesitant to switch for various reasons. While initially skeptical, I’ve been a happy prepaid customer for nearly a decade, and I’ll dispel some of the stigmas to help you decide on the best option. How Prepaid Phone Plans Work When Traditional Cell Phone Service is Better Better Network Reliability Prepaid vs. Traditional Phone Plans How Prepaid Phone Plans Work Your daily experience with a prepaid plan is similar to traditional postpaid plans. The primary difference is that you pay upfront each month for prepaid plans versus at the end of the month.  Prepaid plans such as T-Mobile Prepaid offer unlimited domestic talk, text, and 5G data at a low monthly cost and no credit check. You can cancel at any time fee-free. You also receive complimentary Magenta Status and other perks for extra savings. Here is a glimpse at what to expect as a new prepaid customer: Setup: The onboarding process is easy. For example, I kept my existing phone number and device. I received my SIM card by mail and activated it for free online without losing service.  Pay-as-you-go: Prepay in full upfront monthly to know exactly how much you will spend. There are no hidden monthly fees or variable expenses Nationwide coverage: Your voice and data coverage works across the entire traditional service map. Enjoy fast download speeds, although reduced speeds are possible if you’re a very high data user and are connected to a busy cell tower.  Bring your own device: Prepaid plans provide instant savings when your current device doesn’t need an immediate upgrade. Recurring upgrades also increase your traditional monthly plan cost as you pay off over the phone over the contract duration.  As a college student on a limited budget, I was originally a prepaid customer to afford basic phone service. but I switched to a traditional plan for the additional perks I could now afford after graduation. When I no longer benefited from expensive traditional plans, I returned to pay-as-you-go.   Prepaid plan choices and additional benefits have greatly improved over the years from a no-frills alternative. These perks make switching substantially easier and not miss your traditional plan. Overall, I’m very happy with my service experience and have zero intentions of switching back to a traditional contract with strict cancellation policies and a higher monthly cost. Budget-Friendly Plans Many people switch to prepaid services because their monthly costs are predictable and affordable. You can easily pay $10 to $50 less per month for unlimited data plans. The potential savings compound when you have multiple lines, like I do. For example, T-Mobile Prepaid unlimited data plans start at $50, and additional lines cost only $30 each (plus fees and taxes). Plus, you enjoy free online activation. However, you could pay $100 or more for unlimited talk, text, and data (along with a bunch of features you may not need) at traditional carriers.  Additionally, a recent J.D. Power study reports that the average monthly cell phone bill is $141. Prepaid plans can provide everything you need at a bargain price. Multiple prepaid phone plans and device-only data plans are available. An unlimited data plan can be your best option while paying less than a traditional plan if you’re just looking for the basics.  Your potential savings increase if you’re a light mobile data user and can get a capped plan to surf the web or stream when you’re not connected to home or public wifi.   Reliable Coverage You have access to the same voice and data nationwide network as traditional customers. T-Mobile Prepaid operates on the largest 5G network in the United States. It’s also possible to enjoy some of the fastest premium data speeds while on their 5G network.  It’s easy to check the coverage map to estimate your data speeds at your home address and frequently visited locations. However, it’s worth pointing out that prepaid customers will experience data throttling before traditional users in busy areas, such as a high-density downtown district or a major sporting event. Further, certain prepaid networks may not lack domestic roaming capabilities. This varies widely based on the plan you chose. These limitations are due to prepaid carriers operating on the excess capacity of traditional networks. You’re more likely to avoid this drawback by opting for prepaid plans directly from a carrier like T-Mobile instead of another third-party mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) leasing bandwidth from the traditional carrier.    No Lengthy Contracts The flexibility of paying month-to-month and canceling when you need to is another compelling advantage.  There are no penalties if you cancel after several months or want to temporarily pause your service. You can also upgrade or downgrade plans penalty-free. As a prepaid customer, you may need to buy more premium data or switch to a higher plan tier mid-month if needed. You will still know exactly how much you’re paying before upgrading. However, this is not the case with T-Mobile Prepaid. Contrary to popular belief, pay-as-you-go plans are not strictly for cash-strapped customers. This flexibility complements our society’s preference for on-demand subscriptions where you can adjust and personalize instantly and penalty-free. No Credit Checks You won’t encounter a hard credit check as you bring your existing device or pay in full for a new phone. This is beneficial if you’re repairing your credit history or have thin credit.  Another misconception is that prepaid plans are primarily for individuals with bad credit. Many prepaid customers have good or excellent credit.  Traditional plans are more likely to require a credit check to qualify for service. In particular, when you need to upgrade to a new phone to preview your financing options. Admittedly, I don’t own the newest phones, but I buy used cell phones that last for several years at competitive prices. Paying several hundred dollars instead of $1,000 or more for a brand-new device helps me avoid financial stress. Customer Perks Prepaid plans may have the reputation of not offering additional benefits beyond affordable and reliable phone service. However, customers can enjoy discounts for various services. T-Mobile Prepaid customers can enjoy several perks, including: Magenta Status: Exclusive discounts on entertainment and travel. T-Mobile Tuesdays: Claim gifts and win prizes weekly through the T Life app.  Smartphone Equality: This program can help you qualify for $0 down and no credit check on phone upgrades when you switch to T-Mobile’s postpaid plans after 12 months of on-time payments.   Customers can also receive complimentary Scam Block to prevent junk calls, free wi-fi calling, and mobile hotspot on all prepaid plans. Certain carriers may require a premium plan for similar perks, which may not be worth the extra monthly cost for you.   I’m happy to observe that prepaid services have started offering more membership benefits than when I first switched to month-to-month plans. The discount potential depends on your spending habits and interests. It’s reassuring to have more ways to save beyond a basic phone plan.  When Traditional Cell Phone Service is Better There are several times when sticking to a postpaid plan is ideal, even if you pay more per month. Exclusive Discounts Traditional plans can be more affordable when you qualify for multi-line discounts or work for a qualifying employer. First responders, healthcare workers, government employees, and military members are usually eligible for discounts that make postpaid plans cost similar or less. It’s worth your time to see which discounts you qualify for. My previous employer offered discounted contracts, which is one reason why I remained a postpaid customer for several years before deciding to switch. I periodically compare prices to ensure I’m paying the lowest price for my data package. It’s a great opportunity to check out the latest offers and potentially find a newer yet cheaper plan as phone companies constantly change their offerings. Financing and Insurance Traditional phone plans are better if you want the newest phones without paying in full upfront. Device trade-in offers can defray your total cost to reduce your monthly contract price.  Not everyone wants to or is able to bring their own device or pay upfront for a replacement phone, as prepaid plans require. Carrier financing may require a credit check and a contract, but it can make the difference in having service or not. Prepaid plans don’t offer financing or insurance, which can make buying a new device unaffordable or too risky. However, it can still be worth looking for purchase discounts on recent models. If phone financing is better for your situation, strive to improve your credit score to 700 or above. Doing so can help you easily qualify for the best deals.   Higher Data Caps Most prepaid and postpaid unlimited data plans offer high-speed access in most situations. However, the premium data allowances, video streaming quality, and mobile hotspot access can differ considerably. Below are a couple of points to consider: Mobile hotspot: Postpaid customers can also receive more complimentary high-speed data than prepaid customers before the excess usage reduces to 3G download speeds.  Video streaming: Traditional plans are more likely to stream up to 4K UHD (2160p) versus DVD quality (480p). The plan disclosures distinguish the maximum playback quality. Better Network Reliability Traditional phone plans usually cost more yet are less likely to experience service disruptions during peak usage hours or in areas with spotty coverage.  Having reception when a prepaid phone is still searching for service can be worth the peace of mind. Consider asking friends and family about their coverage experience. For many, the prepaid network capabilities are more than sufficient, but it’s worth considering your lifestyle and reception needs.  More Plan Benefits Traditional plans typically provide more ancillary services, which can help you save money and improve your quality of life. Most perks pertain to streaming apps, travel, or communicating with friends and family in other countries. Postpaid plans are more likely to offer the following perks: Complimentary video streaming subscriptions 4K UHD video streaming quality International talk, text, and data In-flight wifi Device upgrade offers These additional features may narrow the price difference between plans if you currently pay for similar add-ons. Dedicated Customer Care Traditional customers may receive priority account support over prepaid customers. Some prepaid companies don’t even offer live phone support, but only live chat to help deliver cheaper plans. Thankfully, all T-Mobile wireless customers can reach a service representative by phone or online. In-person assistance is also available at local T-Mobile stores.  As you may rarely contact customer support, this potential service difference can be a non-factor during your comparison process.    Prepaid vs. Traditional Phone Plans PrepaidTraditionalContract LengthMonth-to-monthUp to 24 monthsMonthly CostUsually lowerPotentially higherPayment DateStart of the monthly billing cycleEnd of the monthly cycleDiscountsMulti-line discountsAutopay, multi-line, and employer affiliationsCredit Check NoneSome carriers check credit to open an account. Prepaid plans have fewer strings attached, so you have more control over how much you spend. On the other hand, traditional plans are more luxurious and can be better if you frequently use your phone. Final Thoughts Prepaid phone plans often provide similar coverage and all the talk, text, and data you need at more affordable prices. Consider these plans if you want the flexibility of pay-as-you-go service and don’t need carrier-provided upgraded financing. Traditional cell phone plans still make sense if you consume over 50GB of data monthly, need add-on plans, or your profession helps you qualify for valuable discounts. It’s worth comparing prices and features to get the best plan at the lowest cost.
html:
Prepaid cell phone plans are gaining popularity as people look for easy ways to save money on core household expenses. However, potential customers are hesitant to switch for various reasons. While initially skeptical, I’ve been a happy prepaid customer for nearly a decade, and I’ll dispel some of the stigmas to help you decide on the best option.

  1. How Prepaid Phone Plans Work

  2. When Traditional Cell Phone Service is Better

    4. Better Network Reliability

  3. Prepaid vs. Traditional Phone Plans

How Prepaid Phone Plans Work

Your daily experience with a prepaid plan is similar to traditional postpaid plans. The primary difference is that you pay upfront each month for prepaid plans versus at the end of the month. 

Prepaid plans such as T-Mobile Prepaid offer unlimited domestic talk, text, and 5G data at a low monthly cost and no credit check. You can cancel at any time fee-free. You also receive complimentary Magenta Status and other perks for extra savings.

Here is a glimpse at what to expect as a new prepaid customer:

  • Setup: The onboarding process is easy. For example, I kept my existing phone number and device. I received my SIM card by mail and activated it for free online without losing service. 
  • Pay-as-you-go: Prepay in full upfront monthly to know exactly how much you will spend. There are no hidden monthly fees or variable expenses
  • Nationwide coverage: Your voice and data coverage works across the entire traditional service map. Enjoy fast download speeds, although reduced speeds are possible if you’re a very high data user and are connected to a busy cell tower. 
  • Bring your own device: Prepaid plans provide instant savings when your current device doesn’t need an immediate upgrade. Recurring upgrades also increase your traditional monthly plan cost as you pay off over the phone over the contract duration. 

As a college student on a limited budget, I was originally a prepaid customer to afford basic phone service. but I switched to a traditional plan for the additional perks I could now afford after graduation. When I no longer benefited from expensive traditional plans, I returned to pay-as-you-go.  

Prepaid plan choices and additional benefits have greatly improved over the years from a no-frills alternative. These perks make switching substantially easier and not miss your traditional plan.

Overall, I’m very happy with my service experience and have zero intentions of switching back to a traditional contract with strict cancellation policies and a higher monthly cost.

Budget-Friendly Plans

Many people switch to prepaid services because their monthly costs are predictable and affordable. You can easily pay $10 to $50 less per month for unlimited data plans. The potential savings compound when you have multiple lines, like I do.

For example, T-Mobile Prepaid unlimited data plans start at $50, and additional lines cost only $30 each (plus fees and taxes). Plus, you enjoy free online activation. However, you could pay $100 or more for unlimited talk, text, and data (along with a bunch of features you may not need) at traditional carriers. 

Additionally, a recent J.D. Power study reports that the average monthly cell phone bill is $141. Prepaid plans can provide everything you need at a bargain price.

Multiple prepaid phone plans and device-only data plans are available. An unlimited data plan can be your best option while paying less than a traditional plan if you’re just looking for the basics. 

Your potential savings increase if you’re a light mobile data user and can get a capped plan to surf the web or stream when you’re not connected to home or public wifi.  

Reliable Coverage

You have access to the same voice and data nationwide network as traditional customers. T-Mobile Prepaid operates on the largest 5G network in the United States. It’s also possible to enjoy some of the fastest premium data speeds while on their 5G network. 

It’s easy to check the coverage map to estimate your data speeds at your home address and frequently visited locations.

However, it’s worth pointing out that prepaid customers will experience data throttling before traditional users in busy areas, such as a high-density downtown district or a major sporting event. Further, certain prepaid networks may not lack domestic roaming capabilities. This varies widely based on the plan you chose.

These limitations are due to prepaid carriers operating on the excess capacity of traditional networks. You’re more likely to avoid this drawback by opting for prepaid plans directly from a carrier like T-Mobile instead of another third-party mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) leasing bandwidth from the traditional carrier.   

No Lengthy Contracts

The flexibility of paying month-to-month and canceling when you need to is another compelling advantage. 

There are no penalties if you cancel after several months or want to temporarily pause your service. You can also upgrade or downgrade plans penalty-free.

As a prepaid customer, you may need to buy more premium data or switch to a higher plan tier mid-month if needed. You will still know exactly how much you’re paying before upgrading. However, this is not the case with T-Mobile Prepaid.

Contrary to popular belief, pay-as-you-go plans are not strictly for cash-strapped customers. This flexibility complements our society’s preference for on-demand subscriptions where you can adjust and personalize instantly and penalty-free.

No Credit Checks

You won’t encounter a hard credit check as you bring your existing device or pay in full for a new phone. This is beneficial if you’re repairing your credit history or have thin credit. 

Another misconception is that prepaid plans are primarily for individuals with bad credit. Many prepaid customers have good or excellent credit. 

Traditional plans are more likely to require a credit check to qualify for service. In particular, when you need to upgrade to a new phone to preview your financing options.

Admittedly, I don’t own the newest phones, but I buy used cell phones that last for several years at competitive prices. Paying several hundred dollars instead of $1,000 or more for a brand-new device helps me avoid financial stress.

Customer Perks

Prepaid plans may have the reputation of not offering additional benefits beyond affordable and reliable phone service. However, customers can enjoy discounts for various services.

T-Mobile Prepaid customers can enjoy several perks, including:

  • Magenta Status: Exclusive discounts on entertainment and travel.
  • T-Mobile Tuesdays: Claim gifts and win prizes weekly through the T Life app. 
  • Smartphone Equality: This program can help you qualify for $0 down and no credit check on phone upgrades when you switch to T-Mobile’s postpaid plans after 12 months of on-time payments.  

Customers can also receive complimentary Scam Block to prevent junk calls, free wi-fi calling, and mobile hotspot on all prepaid plans. Certain carriers may require a premium plan for similar perks, which may not be worth the extra monthly cost for you.  

I’m happy to observe that prepaid services have started offering more membership benefits than when I first switched to month-to-month plans. The discount potential depends on your spending habits and interests. It’s reassuring to have more ways to save beyond a basic phone plan. 

When Traditional Cell Phone Service is Better

There are several times when sticking to a postpaid plan is ideal, even if you pay more per month.

Exclusive Discounts

Traditional plans can be more affordable when you qualify for multi-line discounts or work for a qualifying employer. First responders, healthcare workers, government employees, and military members are usually eligible for discounts that make postpaid plans cost similar or less.

It’s worth your time to see which discounts you qualify for. My previous employer offered discounted contracts, which is one reason why I remained a postpaid customer for several years before deciding to switch.

I periodically compare prices to ensure I’m paying the lowest price for my data package. It’s a great opportunity to check out the latest offers and potentially find a newer yet cheaper plan as phone companies constantly change their offerings.

Financing and Insurance

Traditional phone plans are better if you want the newest phones without paying in full upfront. Device trade-in offers can defray your total cost to reduce your monthly contract price. 

Not everyone wants to or is able to bring their own device or pay upfront for a replacement phone, as prepaid plans require. Carrier financing may require a credit check and a contract, but it can make the difference in having service or not.

Prepaid plans don’t offer financing or insurance, which can make buying a new device unaffordable or too risky. However, it can still be worth looking for purchase discounts on recent models.

If phone financing is better for your situation, strive to improve your credit score to 700 or above. Doing so can help you easily qualify for the best deals.  

Higher Data Caps

Most prepaid and postpaid unlimited data plans offer high-speed access in most situations. However, the premium data allowances, video streaming quality, and mobile hotspot access can differ considerably.

Below are a couple of points to consider:

  • Mobile hotspot: Postpaid customers can also receive more complimentary high-speed data than prepaid customers before the excess usage reduces to 3G download speeds. 
  • Video streaming: Traditional plans are more likely to stream up to 4K UHD (2160p) versus DVD quality (480p). The plan disclosures distinguish the maximum playback quality.

Better Network Reliability

Traditional phone plans usually cost more yet are less likely to experience service disruptions during peak usage hours or in areas with spotty coverage. 

Having reception when a prepaid phone is still searching for service can be worth the peace of mind. Consider asking friends and family about their coverage experience.

For many, the prepaid network capabilities are more than sufficient, but it’s worth considering your lifestyle and reception needs. 

More Plan Benefits

Traditional plans typically provide more ancillary services, which can help you save money and improve your quality of life. Most perks pertain to streaming apps, travel, or communicating with friends and family in other countries.

Postpaid plans are more likely to offer the following perks:

  • Complimentary video streaming subscriptions
  • 4K UHD video streaming quality
  • International talk, text, and data
  • In-flight wifi
  • Device upgrade offers

These additional features may narrow the price difference between plans if you currently pay for similar add-ons.

Dedicated Customer Care

Traditional customers may receive priority account support over prepaid customers. Some prepaid companies don’t even offer live phone support, but only live chat to help deliver cheaper plans.

Thankfully, all T-Mobile wireless customers can reach a service representative by phone or online. In-person assistance is also available at local T-Mobile stores. 

As you may rarely contact customer support, this potential service difference can be a non-factor during your comparison process.   

Prepaid vs. Traditional Phone Plans

Both plan types provide voice, text, and unlimited high-speed data. Prepaid plans have fewer strings attached, so you have more control over how much you spend. On the other hand, traditional plans are more luxurious and can be better if you frequently use your phone.

Final Thoughts

Prepaid phone plans often provide similar coverage and all the talk, text, and data you need at more affordable prices. Consider these plans if you want the flexibility of pay-as-you-go service and don’t need carrier-provided upgraded financing.

Traditional cell phone plans still make sense if you consume over 50GB of data monthly, need add-on plans, or your profession helps you qualify for valuable discounts. It’s worth comparing prices and features to get the best plan at the lowest cost.
